Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. >Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

Clair time, after an excessively long and pointless Rocket and grinding session.
Plan? Lead Parasect, Spore Gyarados and sucks him dry I guess.

Kingdra next, I try to switch back to Parasect in hopes of more Sleep spreading, but take too much damage from Not Hydro Pump.
No problem, Miltank can stall as long as is needed and eventually win.
Gyarados comes back in, I switch to Sudowoodo, get a Rock Slide miss after which Gyarados waves up and deals notable damage before falling to a more successful Rock Slide.
Second Dragonair comes out, at which point I go to Girafarig, failing to get the kill due to Paralysis before going back to Mommy Milkers for a lossless win.

Did not go ideally, but good enough.

You can pre scout the areas and count beaches/caves as seperate. You can also give yourself bonus gym catch attempts with whatever rules you want to apply. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53072163
>Lance
I had a plan for this involving Agility Passing for the Mamoswine sweep, unfortunately that was no longer an option.
So before the battle, I give Miltank Thunderbolt, and Mamoswine Ice Beam.
Miltank leads, and it turns out, Gyarados struggles with SubMilk too, eventually falling to weather phenomena caused by a cow. Something about Greek mythology goes here.
Unfortunately, this is where it all goes downhill. I need to get Mamoswine in safely, but Miltank can't tank the strongest of the Dragonites indefinitely. Eventually I'm forced to switch in hopes of Outrage hitting in confusion, going to Sudowoodo instead, as probably the most expendable of the team.
He's able to Rock Slide the Dragonite, leading to the second one to come in. I'm not sure which one it is, so I stay in. Turns out it went for Thunder, which would've been a safe switch for Mamoswine. RIP Sudowoodo, your sacrifice won't be forgotten.
Mamoswine puts the DNite to ice, leading to Charizard.
I chose to believe Ancient Power would KO. I was wrong. Should've switched to Magcargo. Two hits was still enough, but Mamoswine is at critical health.
And Lance elects to throw out Dragonite instead of Aerodactyl.
So Lance is down to just Aerodactyl now. I switch to Magcargo here, not wanting to lose Mamoswine, and then go for Yawn. Magcargo lives at critical health, and it's clear that a sack is needed. In the end, while it's certainly the wrong choice in terms of future success, it's time for the milk factory to close down. RIP Miltank, what an absolute unit.
After this, Mamoswine comes in to clean house with Ice Beam + Ice Shard.

Mistakes were definitely made here. Mostly that I lost a lot of utility because of the fight vs. Bruno. I probably could've also shaved losing Miltank vs. Lance. That said, we're still living. I'm not sure how to rebuild from here, but I have some options.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

For the retards that apparently can't be bothered to read from the rentry site, this is how you dump logs:

1. Download the required userscript (Download tampermonkey or the equivalent based on your browser of choice if you havent beforehand)
2. Select the character you want to get the logs for
3. Click the 3 dots in the top right corner and press "View Saved Chats"
4. Soon, a blue "Download" button should appear. It should download your logs as a .json file
5. Go to dump.nopanda.io and dump your logs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Credit goes to RageGamingVideos, as seen here: https://youtu.be/LMZh-u4MqLA

The below is what you will need:

Vaporeon @ Covert Cloak
Ability: Water Absorb
EVs: 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA
Modest Nature
- Aqua Ring
- Acid Armor
- Calm Mind
- Stored Power

Here are the instructions on how to use Vaporeon properly against Greninja:

>Turn 1:
Use Acid Armor. This will help you survive the first attacks from the frog.
>Turn 2:
Use Aqua Ring. It will remain active until you faint.
>Turn 3:
Use Stored Power. By Turn 4, the frog will forcibly reset your stats, so it’s better to chip some of its health instead of wasting a turn.
>Turn 4 and beyond:
By now, the frog would have put up its shield, so it’s time to set up.
First, use Acid Armor x3 times.
Second, use Calm Mind x6 times.
Third, use the “Go All Out” cheer to buff your attacks.
Fourth, use Stored Power until the frog faints.

>“Do I need to keep anything else in mind?”
Greninja’s Nightslash is your biggest threat due to its higher crit rate. Should it ever crit twice in a row, don’t risk it, use a Heal Cheer. Vaporeon in this configuration should be able to tank two hits.

>“Do I need to activate the tera type?”
Not at all, you’ll have all the firepower you need to defeat the frog after the lengthy and boring set up.

https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?

posts.com: Why would you ever want to remove a vitamin

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53054649
Vitamins only benefit the pokemon when it is hatched.
What good is a vitamin on a pokemon, if you don't hatch that egg anymore?
It doesn't do anything but change the time, and points you get from hatching pokemon.

Meaning removing it, won't do anything to the pokemon's stats, unless you want to start hatching the eggs again.

Its good they allow you to reallocate it to a pokemon of which can make better use of it for your hatching habits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53088285
>and that would be venom, not poison

No, that would be poison. Venom needs to be injected into the blood stream to cause any damage. Poison can be effective topically, inhaled, ingested, or injected. You can drink snake venom and be fine (generally), but doing the same with poison would kill you. Seeing as togepi just releases this into the air, it would be poison. This is why poison arrow frogs are called such, they secrete poisons and if you touch them you will die.

Hey Nishida simps, anti-Nishidafriend here. Just saw this Japanese-exclusive Nidoking promo for the first time. Honestly looks good. I think the greatest downfall of a lot of Nishida cards of this era is her reliance on slightly-edited stock backgrounds (the same issue with a lot of Sugimori cards) or her tendency to just phone in backgrounds. Like look at the Vending Cubone from the last thread. The Cubone itself is nicely rendered, and she even has some decent texture work on the skull -- it actually looks like bone! But whatever it is the Cubone's hiding behind looks horrendous. It's blurry and fuzzy, even though it's the same distance away from us as the Cubone.

But the Nidoking here looks great. Not a lot of detail in the background, but it works with the Nidoking -- they look like they're both from the same drawing, rather than one being superimposed on the other. And the Nidoking looks good! You've got dark darks, bright whites, a good sense of depth. Her standard fogginess works here with all these jets of steam. Just a pretty nice-looking Ni-shit-a card.

Because the lawsuit was specifically about pic related. Yuri Geller claimed Dark Kadabra was an "evil" caricature of him. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53091992
Part of what I like about Komiya is the "painterly" quality of his work. I'm not sure if he's still using paints and pastels and shit, but his work still feels analog, and if it is all done in illustration software, it still gives a decent impression of brush strokes and physical mark making. A lot of these newer Komiya ripoffs (and I don't actually mean that, I like most of these artists you've brought up) feel very digital. Not that that's bad or anything -- I think honesty of materials is usually good. But I still like the feeling Komiya's work gives off.

Apart from that, I think Komiya is "overrated" or at least more highly regarded than a number of other illustrators with similar styles because he's been with the TCG since almost the beginning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53096563
Definitely helps to start with a specific goal in mind and broaden it as you fill out your collection. Focus, especially early on, will keep you from getting overwhelmed. If you collect things you’re genuinely interested in, instead of things that seem like good “investments” or something, the knowledge (and yeah, the value) will come naturally. Don’t buy cards in shitty condition just to fill out your collection — if you’re anything like me, you’ll just end up buying a mintier copy later on anyway. Just save the money and put it toward a copy you’d want to show off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53096646
Tips on collecting

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53096726
Awesome. Solid goal, exactly how I started. I filled up a binder with base-fossil + black star promos and southern islands.

I meant to complete all the Neo sets, but then the Neo boom transitioned into the pandemic boom, and now it’s a huge pain in the ass to find raw cards in decent shape.

And just go for whatever condition works for you. When I first started, I just bought up everything I found that I didn’t already own, and I ended up getting heavily scratched or creased or dirty cards that I didn’t really want. I was just cautioning against that kind of attitude. The hobby generally rewards patience.

Oh and as far as patience goes, auctions are a solid way to get cheap cards. Put in a lot of lowball bids on cards you want. You won’t always win, but you can pretty often get cards for well under the average recent sale price.

>>53089024
The probpem isn't being just too easy or hard. It's the game itself being inconsistent. For the first ~4 gyms, it works out pretty evenly, maybe easy if you don't have a full team, but then after Morty the levels drop out from under you, and depending on what you did early the result in gyms 5-7 is different:
> 1. Only had one/a few pokemon:
your team is probably at a higher level, you don't gain levels very much anymore, but you're already strong enough to quickly sweep through
> 2. already had 6:
Your team is even more likely to stop gaining experience ,but you also are about at the npc levels, so it's just low power STAB spam thanks to the weaker movepools unevolved/lower level mons generally have
>3. had a few, adding to the team:
the worst of both worlds, you have a few pokemon that are strong and can sweep, but any new additions will be weak and won't gain levels, so you're stuck with whatever it has when you catch it

Depending on which situation you're in, either you get to Clair and the league at their level and continue without much issue (this would be option 1), or your team is now relatively underleveled and still mot at their full potential, so it's more boring battles or grinding against the routes to get those last evos/moves (this is usually options 2 and 3)

And then no matter which one you were this time, you get to Kanto, the gyms are weaker, and it's just a casual walk around the region to destroy everything before being 10-20 levels under Red.

Other regions avoid this inconsistency thanks to the exp all, which does make them easy, but also much more well rounded to allow different playstyles instead of having drasitcally different experiences depending on when you caught your party.

>>53081614
Level curve is simply a way to add some difficulty to the game. Fighting red's team with level 40/level 50 mons is a completely different experience to fighting him with level 80 mons, and maxing out red's levels in other to raise the overall level curve means that less thoughtful players can't simply beat him by overlevelling him. The other reason behind the level curve is to make certain special mons like dragonite and tyranitar harder to get, as you need to actually commit to training their pre evolutions before obtaining them - and that only makes them feel that much special.

The other big misconception about gen 1 and gen 2 is that they are all about pokemon battling and thus they are bad because they are not filled with competitive pokemon with optimized move sets, because they and monster COLLECTING games where the real challenge is meeting and capturing as many pokemon as possible, not PvP battling. Gen 2 was the last gen where legendaries were actually elusive rather than handed to you by the plot, even suicune in crystal can be entirely missed if you don't want to follow him - and despite adding the battle tower as a true test for competitive pvp movesets, the real final challenge in that game isn't battling red, it's capturing the three legendary beasts just so you have a chance at battling and capturing ho oh.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not gonna spam (you)s, you guys know who this is for.

Personally, I’ve never had an issue using more than 6 mons in GSC. But I wanna emphasize: that is 100% because I don’t consider grinding an issue.
People don’t see it this way these days but back then, spending ~hour each day leveling your mons in a nearby area, while engaging in side activities like the game corner, berry collecting, trainer rematches, bug catching contests etc in the downtime to break up the monotony, all that stuff, that WAS the content. That WAS the gameplay. Maybe one day you’d get lucky and run into a rare encounter on your way through an area, maybe you’d get a call about a swarm, maybe you finally win the bug catching contest, etc etc, each day brings with it potential for new experiences, it’s not always about clearing all of what technically counts as “content” in a given area ASAP and then moving on, you MAKE the content by creating your own story using the tools the game gives you. For me that means catching and training like 10-15 mons as I progress, and fully embracing the slower, routine based playstyle that asks of me. For others? Maybe they don’t really want to - and that’s ok. Those players can use proportionally less Pokémon, thus allowing them to progress through the game in a suitably swifter manor.
BUT
When people constantly whine about aspects of the game that aid my playstyle, getting in the way of theirs? Yea, I’m sorry, but it just sounds like you’re playing the game wrong, or more specifically, it sounds like you’re going into the game expecting it to give you an experience it’s not designed to, and then get mad when it doesn’t. You’re not “objectively wrong” or some shit, those issues you’re complaining about “exist”, sure, I wont be disingenuous with you there, but whether or not they’re “issues” at all is a matter of perspective, it may hinder your experience but it bolsters mine

Based GSC enjoyer. The games really aren’t that difficult, but as with every pokemon game, the player has a lot of control over the difficulty of the experience. The number of times I’ve seen / heard of people doing long grinds for Red is proof enough that some players simply don’t “get” GSC, meaning they aren’t familiar enough with the mechanics to know that Red (and other trainers) are manageable even when massively underleveled.

I think too many players come into GSC expecting modern mechanics and wind up ruining their own experience. As for those who claim to have always hated GSC after playing RBY, I genuinely can’t understand why; people typically don’t elaborate on that very well.

I will also say that HGSS, good as it is, exacerbates some of the issues people have with GSC, and I think that has made the opinion of Gen 2 more negative with some people, even if they haven’t played the original games. HGSS really would have benefited from making more changes to Johto and rebalancing the Kanto / Johto mon for the attack split. When it comes to rebalancing abilities and stats, I’m not sure why Game Freak is so hesitant. They’ve fucked up several lines over the years with the special stat split and attack split, and a lot of early abilities suck.

posts.name: Latias4Life

Good to be back!

First off, I made a Secret Garden themed phone notification sound for people to download and use if they want. I use it on Telegram! :D

Here: https://vocaroo.com/1i18eBQnqfhD

I also finally watched the two episodes of Pokemon: Aim to be a Pokemon Master with near perfect English translations, and I'm so convinced that it's movie 5 Latias!

- Ash recognizes her for SURE! He even asked her what was wrong point blank when all she was doing was seeming hostile toward him, like HE knew the behavior was strange for her.

- What are the odds that they'd decide to introduce an entirely different Latias? Makes little sense.

- I think it's just been too long since she last saw him, and she's been through too much. Also, she got hit pretty hard in the air and was possibly disoriented.

- You can tell Latias has the same affinity for him. I think there was a spark of realization when he got hit by the electricity while trying to rescue her from the icy globe. It was almost a "this is my knight in shining armor" way she saw him for a second.

- When she grabbed and flew with him and they held hands, you could tell she was kind of in shock, like she was experiencing old feelings.

- When she flew away at the end, she didn't revert to a "BAKA!" like tsundere personality. She just floated away with a really confused look in her eyes, like, "I need to process this."

Obviously there had to be some sort of conflict that they need to resolve between them. They can't just have Latias follow him around like a lovesick puppy.

Still kind of in shock that Latias beat Misty to having shippy moments. Ash really tended to Latias and seemed so loving... so heartwarming! I had a near perfect translation for episode 2 and Misty was obsessed with that clauncher, practically calling it her soulmate. Latias definitely has a better chance! Can't wait to see where this goes! :D

posts.name: Latias4Life

Gonna practice writing a couple small slices of life in case I want to finish my fic.

Pokemon Master ~ Day 27

Silvery moonlight cascaded down through the canopy of trees that sprawled in abundance throughout the Secret Garden. A June breeze caused branches and leaves to sway, creating scintillating moving patterns over a certain eon's minuscule and reflectively white feathers.

The humid, subtropical climate of Altomare was proving unusually cool this time of year with warm, moist air dominating, but occasional chilly gusts coming from a competing storm front to the north.

One such gust caused a certain human Pokemon master to shiver and whine in his sleep. Latias gazed at Ash with her golden eyes, taking in the details of his prone form, such as the way his skin scrunched up and formed little pimples, and how his dark, spiky coal black hair fluttered against his exposed forehead. He was fully covered the way humans seemed to prefer to be in public, but Latias wondered and fretted over if it was enough.

He looked so soft and vulnerable to the psychic and dragon type, his body far less powerful and resilient than her own. However, it was the strength of his heart and determination of his mind that caused Latias' heart to latch on to him, deciding to share with him any physical advantages she could.

"Laaaa," she whispered to her love as softly as she could before gently sliding a claw beneath his side and draping the other over him. In this embrace, she pulled him close to her soft, warm jetlike body, all exposed human skin becoming immersed in her down. The effort caused the large hammock they were sharing to swing back and forth, creating further friction against their spooning bodies.

When Ash's shivering stopped, the eon cooed and nestled her neck into the crook of his and closed her eyes. She still wasn't sure what their future held, but for now, having him near was enough. The sound of his heartbeat soon lulled her into a secure slumber.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53087620
>Go to pokemon menu
>Select pokemon
>Click options in bottom right
>Click "appraise"
IV values range from 0 to 15 in each stat. Because PvP uses the fucked up Combat Power system, you want low attack, high defense, and high hit point IVs if you plan to use it in PvP. For PvE, you want it maxed out. If you trade a pokemon, its IVs get rerolled and you have another chance at good IVs, which is why people max out the 100/day trade limit after community days and spotlight hours. Also, "lucky" pokemon have minimum IV values of 12/12/12.

Purifying a pokemon removes the incredible 20% damage boost from its "shadow bonus" in exchange for +2 on each IV stat, which is not even remotely worth it. The only reasons to purify a pokemon is if they benefit more from gaining Return, if you NEED to be able to mega evolve that one in particular, or if you plan to trade it, since you can't trade shadow pokemon. You can also purify shadow shitmons to help build your "purifier" medal, but you don't want to d9 that to pokemon that are actually good.

Pokemon as a franchise is a case study about how a core concept can be so good that no amount of fuckups or mismanagement can make it fail. The 3D models have always looked like shit, game stories are weak at best, bugs are everywhere, generation 6+ is consumed by gimmicks, and upper management has explicitly told us that they would rather make a shitty game and keep costs down than make a good game and spend more money than absolutely necessary. On top of the video games, the card game is a mess and the anime is so well known for not making narrative progress that Ash winning a championship tournament was world wide news.

Despite all of that, I love pokemon

Not only my favorite gen 2 memory but Pokémon overall.
>be eh 7 or 8
>few years after game came out
>get gameboy and crystal version for Christmas
>keeps me distracted from chaos at home
>play with my friends who come from wealthy family at after school daycare
>on my way to catch the beasts
>misguided fat kid smacks gameboy out of my hands and trips me
>I fall straight down into stomach and knees
>Out of breath and gameboy is totally kill
>regain breath, notice fallen gameboy and run off crying
>go to PE area where no one is and just breakdown in grass
>find a gold necklace with a locket in grass
>open locket and see fancy pic of a girl I know and some man
>wipe tears away and go to find her
>find her in cafeteria
>give her necklace and she kisses me on the cheek and thanks me at least 10 times
>turns her back on me as she shows her friends she found it and I go back to empty PE area
>lay down on grass and see a cloud shaped like a big pretty bird
>makes me smile
>hear running sounds and “hey anon!” From hallway
>it’s cool rich friend and his sister
>gives me my crystal version cart
>mentions how he has 2 gameboy advances for trading and I can have one
>in disbelief so I hug him tight
>sister hugs both of us
>look back at bird cloud
>go back to cafeteria to get Hawaiian Punch and goldfish and we catch the beasts and ho-oh together
I will NEVER forget you Dallas. We were both pure of heart.

We really need to define what exactly is iceberg material to begin with before doing this OP. As far as I know, iceberg infographics are used to show people dark and dubious secrets of the internet that not many people knows. The deeper the iceberg goes, the harder it is to find such information unless people dive deeper into the internet infrastructure. Many secrets can't be found on the surface (Google/search engines) while some can only be found in dubious imageboards or hobby websites (4chan/discord). The darkest secrets can only be uncovered by using TOR or P2P networks. This is how an iceberg should work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Peak of the iceberg
Very well known facts. Things that you can find and read from Google search without clicking on the link.
>Platform of the iceberg
Well known facts. Things you can find and read from websites listed on google search.
>Water level surface
Known facts. Things and pages that are being promoted on wiki homepages.

^^Anything above this level must come from TPCi themselves.^^

>Below water level
Less known facts. Things that you can find after clicking several layers of links from initial page that you originally clicked from google or wiki.
>Stem of the iceberg
Lesser known facts. Things that are being spoken regularly on imageboards, blogs, reddit, discord, etc.

vvMost (if not all) of stuffs below this level are +18 stuffs.vv

>Twilight zone
Not well known facts. Things that seldom being shared on degenerate imageboards such as /vp/. If you ask a typical pokemon fan, they may or may not know about them.
>Bottom of the iceberg
Mostly rumours. Things that rarely being talked about. Things that lack verifiable sources. You will never read about these things on wiki pages and their topics are highly regulated by admins.
>Below the iceberg
Mysterious rumours. No one knows how they started or where did they come from. Once in a while, someone will mention them on imageboards like 4chan. But there is absolutely no way to find and verify their sources.

Imagine her situation: she is small, so she can't last too long in the wild, so she created that big mouth to defend herself. Now, her habitat are caves, wo if she can't feed on berries and roots, she has to eat minerals to survive, giving her the Steel type.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53058241
Yeah, the way it's teeth are placed, along the outside rather than the inside, reminds me of crocodiles, meaning it likely doesn't use them to chew, at least not the things that can actually fit inside of them, unlike steel beams. And since the 'neck' that connects the jaws to Mawile's head is so small, it probably can't swallow anything either. If it did, it'd need to have an esophagus going down through the brain, which just sounds like a disaster waiting to happen.
Which means that Mawile's hind jaws probably act like a venus fly-trap, using secretions to dissolve whatever it holds inside and absorb the nutrients released down through the 'neck'. It would arrive at the brain first, so it'd also be a good biological explanation for why Mawile is smart enough to deceive others.

posts.com:
Remove per move PP and make it a pool per pokemon per battle. Moves now cost 1-8 PP, Each mon has 8 PP pool, restores 2 each turn.

Instead of choosing a move, you can now dodge, block, and throw partners (in non single battles).
Moves never miss unless the opponent dodges.
Blocking reduces received damage.

All types now have statuses associated with them. Each type gets a buff and debuff status effect.

IVs are removed.

Flying is now Wind type.
Pokemon that can fly, float, glide or levitate are in a state of being in the air unless they are grounded. Being in the air makes a mon weak to electric type attacks.
Electric is neutral against Wind types that are not in the air.

Pokemon can have any type as a mutation, and this is 1000x rarer than shinies.
Mutated pokemon have pallete swaps according to their type e.g. fire type pikachu is red/orange.

You can upgrade a pokemon's BST a certain number of times, more if they are initially weak e.g. Caterpie, less or not at all if they are initially strong e.g. Mewtwo.

There absolutely is unpredictability
Every time a batter swings he's going for a home run. But the unpredictability of how and where he hits the ball, the condition of the ball, the wind, whatever wobble imparted onto the ball by the pitcher unconsciously, results in a fairly random outcome in terms of where the ball goes.

Poker is larger than chess by far.
But beyond that, there's a reason that high level chess players like Bobby Fischer talk shit about how predictable and uninteresting chess becomes.
Which is where you get Fischer Random chess and the like. Because RNG makes things better and more skill based.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53093507
Poker is a poor example - variability and probability play a part in Poker, but that is because understanding your odds of winning directly impacts how much you expose yourself. And even then, bluffing, lying, etc. play a significantly greater role in the game. This sort of "risk-taking" in Pokemon is literally just taking a dice roll on if a move will even HIT or a Pokemon will even MOVE. Poker's probability is simply the chance of scoring higher or lower on any given hand. If you had the opportunity to, say, give your Pokemon three rounds of fainting before removal from the battle, I'd see your point. But as most Pokemon go down in 2-3 moves at most, use of a move that inherently has an outright 15%+ chance to fail or do something that breaks the opponent's strategy wide open doesn't quite translate.
The amount of times I've taken a battle off Scald has NOTHING to do with my ELO/Game Skill. Scald is 30% for me and little retard Timmy, and those odds don't influence my decision like they would in a game of Poker.
The two are not comparable.

posts.com:
Pokémon chess.

You pick the Pokémon from tiers for each piece, then play regular chess.

Plays like regular chess, but when a piece takes another, what instead happens is that a regular Pokémon battle ensues between them.

If attacking and succeeds, you take the pieces place like in regular chess, but if you attack and lose, you just remove the attacking piece from play . The defending piece remains in play, but with hp damage.

Game ends when you get checkmated or I guess if your king faints or something idk

And if for some reason it works better with a chess variant, be my guest.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chess_variants

posts.com: Professional author anon here, been thinking about starting a PMD story. What are some Do’s and Don’ts? What would you like and not like to see in a PMD fic?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53092254
There aren't really any set in stone tips. There are stories I've read that follow the usual story beats of "human wakes up a Pokemon, has amnesia, has to save the world with their new friends" and they're enjoyable. There are edgy as fuck stories that up the ante with heavier themes and violence, and with the right approach they can work. It's all dependent on the author and their style. Can you make a story and the world it occurs in believable? Can the characters be cared for by the audience? If you can achieve that, you're golden.

I will say though, my favorites are when people take the formula and run with just the basics. Talking Pokemon with their own society, teams that fulfill jobs and handle issues, some kind of overarching threat/plot, and enough to tie it all together nicely. Don't even have to involve humans or anything of the sort.

the only game I bought since USUM was PLA, but that's cause I don't consider it mainline. Well, it was fun while it lasted, but the singleplayer of these games have just been dying faster after beating all main objectives as early as gen 6, nosediving in gen 8, and more realized in gen 9. One of the damning issues being the phasing out of the Battle Tower; gen 6's Battle Maison was bland, but offered many battle formats. Gen 7's Battle Tree lost the triple/rotation formats, but had the ability to recruit almost every trainer you battled for multi-battle partners as well as a slew of boss trainers (they even used Mega Evolution and Z-moves as well). Gen 8 was an objective downgrade to the Battle Tower as the multi-battle format was removed as well as super singles/doubles with Leon being the only boss character. BDSP offered a watered-down Battle Tree minus the multi-battle format. Gen 9 offers nothing (unless they sell it back to people which would be hilarious, especially if people think it "improves" the game).

I've been sharing around this image of the unusable Pokémon/forms for SV because, unfortunately, some people have things called "expectations." For example, some think the other Kanto starters will be available this spring. Nope. I've seen a post about Dracovish breaking raids. Nope. Sinnoh starters? Going on two gens in a row with not being able to go to a mainline game. PoGO has an upcoming shiny Jirachi event and its only transfer destination will be LAST gen. Anything you see on this list you gotta hope for. "TRUST THE PLAN" as they say.

>>53099636
You've never played the Battle Maison. Or if you have, you didn't figure out it was way easier despite being largely copy-pasted down to the dialogue. It's amazing how much of a difference lack of scaling low leveled Pokemon makes. Like, the Battle Subway isn't perfect, singles are fucked by True Ant (the WiFi mode the Battle Maison lacks can theoretically fix this but theoretical is all it is). But the Battle Maison not only doesn't fix it, but also makes FEAR way too viable in Triples and Doubles. You could make like three teams and hit almost every milestone in the Battle Maison relatively trivially. PWT might be easier in the actual battles, but in teambuilding alone it takes way more effort simply because of the restrictions of the Type Expert Tournaments. Oh, and let's not forget, the Gen 6 engine will lag in triples and rotations, which makes them just a pain to play in a streak in general. And speaking of streaks, the change from having to do 7 in a row to letting you take a break whenever you want is arguably casualization. Could be QoL, but if you want to argue difficulty we have to pick these nits.
Basically, Pokestar Studios is the best facility, I think we can agree on that much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043330
Hey, that's cool. I was just curious since the threads here always seems collector focus.

Radiant Pokemon are Pokemon that you can only have one of in your deck, but they're have powerful effects or attacks. So it's fun to try and choose which Radiant you want to use or work into your deck. Pic rel is one of the most popular ones, discard pile setup and drawing is really good for a lot of decks.

Radiant Eternatus is the main new one from CZ people like. When you bench it, you can search your deck for any two VMAX Pokemon and bench them as well. Which opens up a lot of opportunities for faster VMAX play.

>>53058196
>I was surprised people can just join games without even having the mod
The game is just a sandbox, when you sub to a workshop you're just getting a .json file telling the game to load different images, models, etc
Anybody that joins will just load the same information, the game will actually download these assets to make loading faster but if you don't want to clog your disk space turn Mod Cache off in the options.

>perhaps there should be a Steam group or something for Pokemon matchmaking
There probably is, lots of TTS discords popped up after the death of Global Chat, a shame. You could also host a lobby and post the info here so other anons can join. I don't play much these days but doing drafted/booster deck matches could be fun.

posts.com:
Credit goes to RageGamingVideos, as seen here: https://youtu.be/LMZh-u4MqLA [Open]

The below is what you’ll need:

Vaporeon @ Covert Cloak
Ability: Water Absorb
EVs: 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA
Modest Nature
- Aqua Ring
- Acid Armor
- Calm Mind
- Stored Power

Here are the instructions on how to use Vaporeon properly against Greninja:

>Turn 1:
Use Acid Armor. This will help you survive the first attacks from the frog.
>Turn 2:
Use Aqua Ring. It will remain active until you faint.
>Turn 3:
Use Stored Power. By Turn 4, the frog will forcibly reset your stats, so it’s better to chip some of its health instead of wasting a turn.
>Turn 4 and beyond:
By now, the frog would have put up its shield, so it’s time to set up.
First, use Acid Armor x3 times.
Second, use Calm Mind x6 times.
Third, use the “Go All Out” cheer to buff your attacks.
Fourth, use Stored Power until the frog faints.

>“Do I need to keep anything else in mind?”
Greninja’s Nightslash is your biggest threat due to its higher crit rate. Should it ever crit twice in a row, don’t risk it, use a Heal Cheer. Vaporeon in this configuration should be able to tank two hits.

>“Do I need to activate the tera type?”
Not at all, you’ll have all the firepower you need to defeat the frog after the lengthy and boring set up.

Because when making a direct sequel to one of the most popular games of all time, which RGBY were, you want to keep the OG around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53083071
>Maybe, or Pokémon just aren't violent? I mean same goes for real world animals, most are passive unless u go into their territory or threaten their children, most will run away from u.

NTA, but even acknowledging the parallel between IRL animals and Pokemon, animals can be violent, whether in the wild or under human care. I can't even imagine what territorial conflicts between Pokemon and IRL pre-existing animals would be like, let alone territorial conflicts between Pokemon or between Pokemon and humans looking to exploit whatever natural resource they're sitting on.
I think the argument is that even if we imagine the most ideal situation possible, ie humans don't exploit Pokemon or use them as weapons on an institutional level, violence will inevitably happen due to some incident or other. Even assuming every trainer has the world's and the Pokemon's best interest at heart and strive to do good everywhere, accidents happen.

A single incident of Pokemon violence would be devastating on a scale that currently doesn't exist anywhere other than humans, even more so if a powerful enough specimen is unfortunately involved. We can all easily imagine what the human response would be.

Personally I think the most dangerous thing that could happen long-term is trainers trying to over-optimize Pokemon through selective breeding and ending up with a reality bending powerhouse with the flighty temperament of an Arabian racehorse.

Orbeetle is the golden goose here. Over five miles of great awareness of surroundings is so unbelievably good regardless of the situation. But aura and telepathy are okay bargain bin substitutes.
Solving communication with telepathy is also really good, but not nearly as important since Pokemon typically only does surface level readings, if that.

>Hyper offence bug
I'll get to why, but this is non negotiable. Chicken dinner here is Lokix, but anything with >80 speed and a good offence stat qualifies.

Even in the most games-honest version of this, there's going to be major mon to stay the hell away from. King of this is Malamar, the obnoxiously powerful and expressly evil hypnotist.

Always blitz it. No exceptions.
Think it might be wild and harmless? Blitz it.
Your friend has a new pal? Blitz it.
Delicate political situation and you see one off in the distance minding it's own business? Oh you'd better fucking believe you're gonna blitz it.

Anyways, have fun Brionne lovers. I know I had a lot of fun making it.

>>53080332
None of that implies anything. It doesn't imply relationships, it's simply just written word in the pokedex, which as noted by Masuda may even be ignored if it gets in the way of how they want to portray Pokémon.

Pokémon as intended represent the critters Tajiri interacted with in his childhood while also doubling as good pets in the vain of cats and dogs, something he mentioned and made clear in his 2018 biography but also as early as 1995.

As Takeshi Shudo wrote, the anime staff, which in the planning stages would have likely involved Pokémon creators, decided to think of Pokémon as being like critter from the real world. Shudo in his blog even introduces Pokémon this way, as group of critters inspired by familiar objects and creatures. This is even the viewpoint given to us in the 2012 guide which explicitly tells us Pokémon replace the critters from the real world, and note that it never mentions monsters except not to call Pokémon that.

The series itself is even starting to reject the label monster for Pokémon and SV has dialogue to dissociate the label from Pokémon. Given that the series constructs domesticated Pokémon to be like dogs and cats, both in the way they're treated and how the act, and given that they also want people to view Pokémon as cute little critters and not monsters no one should act shocked when there's a push back against sexualization of what are essentially innocent creatures that occupy the sphere of being a pet and also being natural creatures. That perception lies in the way the series has chosen to construct Pokémon.

Yes. Gengar for example isn't depicted as a lonely entity that's going to harms you or kill you as the pokedex implies. Ash's Gengar, for example, was depicted as an abandoned dog, one commentator on reddit called the debut episode the 'Jurassic Bark' of Pokémon.

You're trying to paint Tajiri as a deviant when evidence suggests that you're wrong on all counts. First because his biography is pretty open of how he thinks of Pokémon. This panel here shows that he thinks of them as being like cats and dogs which is a viewpoint that is reinforced in the following panels as he imagines Pokémon battles as two dog owners in the real world allowing their dogs to fight, according to him the angles Pokémon fights are drawn in are inspired by this. In short it clearly cements his statement. And this isn't something that materialized out of the blue, the 1996 Pokedex guide written by GameFreak has this in one of their sections:

More fearsome than a cat, more kind than kaiju, those are pokemon
People quickly think of Pokemon to be like Kaiju. There's a strong image of Kaiju being evil, but in this world there isn't such a thing. They're friends to humans like dogs and cats.

Tajiri even wrote something similar in 1995 in a book recovered by Dr. Lava. Takeshi Shudo talks about some of these things in his blog as well, for example how they decided Pokémon would eat berries and Pokémon food, basically what visually looks exactly like dry dog food, among other things during the planning stages of the anime.

>>53090641
I appreciate your setting out a coherent, source-based argument. Rare few do on this website.
You are correct in that Tajiri did not intend for either the overt humanisation or sexualisation of Pokémon. Attempts to say otherwise are wrong.
However, over time, the franchise has changed into one where this is arguably the case, that is, the humanisation of Pokemon.
This is partially due to the anime; which, in the name of consistent plotlines, has involved Pokemon as more active characters than bystanders or plot devices.
Most notably of course is Meowth. This is largely for comedic effect, of course, and due to his appearance in early seasons, where the lore was taken far more liberally, should be taken with a grain of salt.
However, various talking, intelligent have appeared since, taking direct, more dramatic roles. Case in point the Lucario in M08, which displays eminent and human characteristics.
As for other examples, the Ninetales seen in "Just waiting for a friend", the Zoroark in "The island of illusions", and the Malamar which frequently appeared in X&Y(Whilst it never talks directly, one can infer its hypnotising of Jenny and blatant intelligence as implying it could if it wanted to)
Admittedly, this is not as present in the games, their focus being on gameplay over story, with the legendaries being the only real exception.
However, we do still see several instances of Pokemon behaving decidedly unlike docile pets or wild animals. The two disguised zoroarks in Lostlorn forest, for instance.
Overall, we can assume GF's stance on pokemon's mental capabilities as being whatever's convenient at a given time. They are intentionally kept vague for narrative ease.
This results in amusing situations such as Sawk or Mr Mime, about as human as Pokémon get, eating from dog bowls on the ground

>>53090849
As for sexualisation, it is decidedly less clear.
To set our perameters, while there can be an argument to be set for something like Salazzle or Gardevoir becoming intimate with a human, using in universe logic, it can be dependent on opinion.
I will also exclude the Sinnoh legend book, as it can be open to various interpretations, i.e that Humans and Pokemon were the same species once.
Cases such as the "Machamp fan club", and NPC claiming that her mightyena is her "boyfriend" will also be disregarded, as they are an arguably comedic piece, and a questionably sincere throwaway line, respectively.
Despite all this, there is one clear cut case; the Froslass in Pokemon: Legends Arceus, who married a human, and possibly had two snorunt children with him.
(While I lack it, there is a compilation of journal entries and other in-game information which explains this further. If someone could post it, I'd be sorely appreciative.)
Granted, this is, more than anything, is a reference to the mythical Yuki-onna, by which Froslass is inspired.
However, if we are to apply this same logic to other Pokemon inspired by mythology, that is that they will inherit traits of their respective legend, then this means that any other mythology-inspired pokemon will perform sexual acts their mythological inspiration would.
To refer to a previous example; Ninetales and Zoroark. Both are inspired by Kitsune, and ergo, would behave much as one does. Due to the noted seductress tendencies of Kitsune (As well as some who form more lasting romantic relationships with humans), we can assume that these two, due to their ability to assume human form (See; Ninetales in "Just waiting for a friend", Zoroark in most depictions), they may also attempt this.
Ergo, while not nearly to the extent which /vp/ threads like to pretend, and with an admittedly restricted amount of Pokémon (The amount of which can be debated), there is accounts of sexual relations between humans and Pokemon.

Leon is the best Champion in ages. A man of action, he takes it upon themselves to deal with local problems and is adored by the public. Your rival is his little brother, trying to live up to big bro's legacy. He is the benchmark for you and all other competitors so he feels important. Even if the game wasn't constantly shilling him, his presence can still be felt.

Steven is rich and he likes rocks. Ok. But why is he the champion? Is completely incidental. It means nothing. He just shows up. Cynthia and Diantha follow the same model. Their status as Champion is secondary to their careers, and never comes up during the story in a meaningful way. Alder fairs better with great characterization, but the whole point of him is that he's retiring. Nobody truly compares to Leon's actions except maybe Lance, who also comes with a cape and a love for Charizard. Try to refute this if you can.

>>53097414
>rather than Ash finally seeing his dream of becoming a Pokemon Master become a reality. Maybe it will pick up later, but there are only eleven episodes, so time is short to deliver on a big plot point in the series that's existed since episode one of the OS.

this interview came out in 2020:

https://dogasu.bulbagarden.net/features/translations/animedia_june2020_daiki_tomiyasu.html

>Animedia: Satoshi's added another dream, hasn't he? "I'm gonna battle Dande again!"

>Daiki Tomiyasu: I had always thought that, personally, the whole "Pokémon Master" thing was really quite vague and so one day I went up to the show's supervisor, Mr. Kunihiko Yuyama, and asked him "So what does Satoshi's "I wanna be a Pokémon Master!" dream mean, exactly?" His response? "It's just the silly dream of a child. It's something for him to idolize." I don't know yet if Satoshi's "have a battle with Dande" thing is going to end up going down as some kind of pie in the sky or not. But I think maybe seeing someone appear in front of you put in so much effort, and then having that be what gets you to get up and give it everything you've got toward your dream is a huge step toward achieving something great. Gou's "I want to capture Mew" dream is similar in that the adults who make this show set up this big, ambiguous goal for him and then spend each episode working to fill in the gaps.

The writers have never really cared or had any grand vision for the series until now. So with all those things considered, I think 4 episodes of Ash figuring out that Pokemon Master is the culmination of his friendships, travels and bonds is probably not hard to do.

Platinum has a lot of cool stuff. There's a lot of fun options like Vespiquen (you can actually soft reset the gender), Magmortar, Rhyperior, Electivire, Lickilicky, Toxicroak, Magnezone, Drapion, Gardevoir/Gallade, and Lucario. The tms for Thunderbolt, Ice Beam, Flamethrower, and Psychic are also really easy to get from the Game Corner so you can always have great coverage.
Torterra is a natural monster with moves like leech seed, earthquake, and curse. It can pull its own weight, you just need something for ice types.

Bronzong - weak to night slash, but it can click Gravity to reduce Greninja's evasion 2 stages and hit it with Psychic attacks
Klefki - Has Lock-On, hits like a wet noodle though
Vaporeon - bulky Haze bot
